title: Sine and Cosine Graphs - identifying a function

content.question:
All coordinates are approximate. Moving from left to right:

The curve begins at point (0 comma 0).

The curve trends up gradually to reach its maximum point at (pi over 2 comma 1).

At point (pi over 2 comma 1), the curve trends down gradually and passes through the x axis at (pi comma 0) to reach its minimum point at (3 pi over 2 comma negative 1). 

At point (3 pi over 2 comma negative 1), the curve trends up gradually to the right and ends at point (2 pi comma 0).

The figure shows the graph of the function <math alttext="f"><semantics><mi>f</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> in the <math alttext="x y"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>-plane. The function <math alttext="f"><semantics><mi>f</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> is either a sine function or a cosine function. Consider an angle in standard position in another <math alttext="x y"><semantics><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>-plane (not shown). The terminal ray of the angle intersects the unit circle at point <math alttext="P"><semantics><mi>P</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>. Which of the following is true about the relationship between <math alttext="f"><semantics><mi>f</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> and <math alttext="P"><semantics><mi>P</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> ?
